ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about functions, derivative, and optimization of functions. It allowed me to practise my pre-calc and develop my calc skills.
Calculus, application of calculus
Calculus

I learned how to re-acquaint myself with AP Calc AB skills at my own pace while also ensuring that I learn material deeply and thoroughly. I was able to deeply learn pre-calc concepts and use them with ease in calculus problems.
I think I really learned how to become a better note taker this semester.

I have always thought that calculus is very hard; however, after taking this course, my perspective changed. The course equipped me with general understanding with basic math and helped change my attitude math. I learned derivatives well and how to apply the knowledge in practical context such as economics.
I learned how effectively students can solidify their understanding of concepts they learn in class if it is also presented to them in several other ways like P-Sets, Workshops, and Office Hours.
I acquired new knowledge of functions and calculations

MATH 110 was a perfect review of basic calculus for me! I took it in high school, but I was not confident in the skills I gained in order to move onto 112 in college -- 110 was, as I said, perfect! Introductions to basic functions, derivative rules, linearization, optimization, exponential functions, and even basic algebra were all reinforced in this class. Because of this, I feel good moving onto 111 with integral calculus.
I gained the knowledge of many topics in math such as optimization and derivatives. I also learned better study habits for math through this course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: this course runs at a good speed and there are many resources outside the lectures to help you learn. It is a little boring, and the mandatory extra sessions make the workload very high. Not exactly difficult but very time-consuming. One weakness would be the lack of feedback after the P-Sets
I liked the small class setting.
strengths - a lot of teacher-student engagement, as well as with teaching assistants.

Strengths: organized, simple to follow, many resources available, people are super willing to teach!
Cons: not as collaborative as an intro math class should be, IMHO
I didn't notice any weaknesses but I thought the pace of the course was just right for our learning.

The strengths of the course is that it keeps students on track because of the assignments due after few days like concepts checks on Fridays or Mondays and problem sets on Wednesday. 
A weakness that can be improved is increasing engagement with students during class hours.

One of the strengths of this course is the support that you have access to. Between workshops, office hours with ULAs, and class times, you are able to get all of your questions answered. The only weakness of this course was the spread of assignments at times. Towards the beginning of the course, p-sets and concept checks were spaced too close together. But this was later adjusted in the course, which leads me to the second strength of this course: instructors take our feedback seriously and apply necessary changes.
Could have gone to class and been more engaged

There is a ton of support for the students in this class: three professors and I forgot how many TAs, all with office hours throughout the week. Plus, there are extra workshops where a TA leads a small group of students in a small p-set the focused on the topics discussed that week in class. The opportunities that 110 students have to seek help are wonderful!
The strengths are that it has very good help outside of class and the TLA's really helped me when I needed it. There really isn't any weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you need the 112 pre-req but you are worried about the preparations you have done in high-school.
Yes I would, I enjoyed the pace of learning.
Yes. I would recommend this course to a beginner in calculus, with relatively weak background in calculus.
Yes, if they find themselves in Math 112 and are going too fast of a pace, or if they don't have a strong pre-calc background from high school
I would definitely recommend this course because I feel like a lot of the things we learned can be applied in everyday life.
Yes, I would recommend  this course for students who want a basis for understanding math. The course can change a student perspective regarding math in general.

Yes I would. I took with the hopes of being able to re-solidify some of the concepts I learned in calculus, but during covid. And I was able to do exactly that. There was a lot of support and it was structured well.
Yes, its a good math class taught well

MATH 110 is a great intro calculus course for students placed in 110 or 112: basically, if you haven't taken calculus, it's great, or if you already have and you need a review, it's also great. I was placed into 112 but I was wary of taking an intro calc course in just one semester. Dropping down to the 110/111 sequence was a great decision (for me, at least) because the content is spread out and developed (the math workshops are great).
Yes, because it helped you understand the basic's of calculus here at Yale.
